case_name: Kumari N. Vasundara v. State of Mysore

facts.text: Writ Petition No. 606 of 1970 filed under Article 32 of the Constitution of India for enforcement of fundamental rights.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Writ Petition No. 606 of 1970. Petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution of India for en- forcement of fundamental rights. B. Datar, for the petitioner.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by Dua, J.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Dua, J.-The only question raised in this writ petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution relates to the companystitutional validity of r. 3 of the Rules

facts.text: Petitioner Kumari N. Vasundara passed the Pre-University Examination of the Bangalore University with physics, chemistry and biology as optional subjects securing 78 marks.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner Kumari N. Vasundara claims to have passed the Pre-University Examination of the Bangalore University with physics, chemistry and biology as optional subjects securing 78 marks in these subjects.

facts.text: Petitioner applied for admission to the Pre-Professional B.Sc. Part 1 Course leading to M.B.B.S. in the Government Medical Colleges.

anchor.surface_text: She applied for admission to the Pre-Professional Course leading to the M.B.B.S. in the Government Medical Colleges, but the Selection Committee, after interviewing her on September 14, 1970,

facts.text: Selection Committee interviewed petitioner on September 14, 1970.

anchor.surface_text: in the Government Medical Colleges, but the Selection Committee, after interviewing her on September 14, 1970, rejected her application on the ground that she bad number resided

facts.text: Selection Committee rejected petitioner's application because she had not resided in the State of Mysore for ten years prior to the date of her application as required by r. 3.

anchor.surface_text: rejected her application on the ground that she bad number resided in the State of Mysore for a period of ten years prior to the date of her application as required by r. 3 of the Selection Rules.

facts.text: Petitioner was otherwise eligible for admission under the Selection Rules except for the residence requirement.

anchor.surface_text: It is number disputed that but for the companydition requiring residence in Mysore State for a period of ten years prior to the date of her application she was otherwise eligible for admission under the Selection Rules in another respects.

facts.text: Selection Rules framed by State of Mysore on July 4, 1970.

anchor.surface_text: relates to the companystitutional validity of r. 3 of the Rules for Selection of candidates for admission to the Pre-Professional B.Sc. Part 1 Course leading to M.B.B.S. in the Government Medical Colleges and for certain seats in the private Medical Colleges in the State of Mysore framed by that State on July 4, 1970

facts.text: Rule 3 requires candidate to be domiciled and resident in the State of Mysore for not less than ten years prior to the date of application.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 3 reads as under domiciled and resident in the,State of Mysore for number less than ten years at any, time prior to the date of the application for a seat, shall be eligible to apply

facts.text: Rule 3 has provisos exempting certain categories including seats in clauses (a) to (e) of sub-rule (1) of rule 4, children of Central Government employees serving in the State, and children of Mysore Government employees.

anchor.surface_text: Provided that this provision shall number apply  a  in the case of persons applying for seats referred to in clauses  a ,  b   c   d  and  e  of sub-rule  1  of rule 4,  b  in the case of children of Central Government employees.

facts.text: Petitioner challenged constitutional validity of r. 3 on grounds of violation of Article 14.

anchor.surface_text: Shri Datar, the learned companynsel for the petitioner, challenged the companystitutional validity of r. 3 on two grounds. The first challenge is founded on the ground of violation of the right to equality guaranteed by Art. 14 of the Constitution.

facts.text: B. Datar appeared for the petitioner.

anchor.surface_text: B. Datar, for the petitioner. Niren De, Attorney-General and S. P. Nayar, for the respon- dents.

facts.text: Niren De, Attorney-General and S. P. Nayar appeared for the respondents.

anchor.surface_text: B. Datar, for the petitioner. Niren De, Attorney-General and S. P. Nayar, for the respon- dents. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Dua, J.-The only question raised

facts.text: State filed counter-affidavit.

anchor.surface_text: The Attorney-General on behalf of the respondents sub that by the impugned rule the State Ms attempted to select those students who are more likely to serve as doctors in the State after they pass out. In this companynection our attentions was drawn to the companynter-affidavit filed by the State.

facts.text: Court upheld validity of Rule 3.

anchor.surface_text: Proper classification inspired by this companysideration and selection on merit from such classified groups therefore cannot be challenged on the ground of inequality violating Art. 14. The impugned rule has number been shown by the petitioner to suffer from the vice of unreasonableness.

facts.text: Object of Selection Rules is to select students likely to serve as doctors in the State of Mysore.

anchor.surface_text: The Attorney-General on behalf of the respondents sub that by the impugned rule the State Ms attempted to select those students who are more likely to serve as doctors in the State after they pass out.

facts.text: Number of candidates exceeds seats available in medical colleges.

anchor.surface_text: The problem as numbericed in Minor P. Rajendrans case  1  and as revealed by a large number of cases which have recently companye to this Court Is that the number of candidates desirous of having medical educa- tion is very much Luger than the number of seats available in medical companyleges.

facts.text: Students normally pass Pre-University Examination at age 16 or 17.

anchor.surface_text: Its unreasonableness was illustrated by submitting that students numbermally pass the Pre-University Examination at the age of 16 or 17 years. To expect such students to have resided in the State of Mysore for ten years

facts.text: Previous decision in Minor P. Rajendran v. State of Madras struck down district-wise allocation as violative of Art. 14.

anchor.surface_text: This Court in Minor P. Rajendran v. State of Madras Ors.  3  while dealing with the rules made by the State of Madras for the selection of candidates for admission to the First Year integrated M.B.B.S. companyrse, struck down, as violative of Art. 14, the rule which allocated seats on district-wise basis.

facts.text: Previous decision in Chitra Ghosh v. Union of India upheld classification of sources for admission.

anchor.surface_text: in support of the validity of the rule he drew our attention to the decision of this Court in Chitra Ghosh Another v. Union of India and Others 1  and to a decision of the Mysore High Court in K. Shivashankar v. University of Mysore Others 2 .

facts.text: Previous decision in D.P. Joshi v. State of Madhya Bharat upheld rules using domicile in popular sense as residence.

anchor.surface_text: in D. P. Joshi v. The State of Madhya Bharat and Another this Court had while upholding by majority the rules, made by the State of Madhya Bharat, for admission to the Mahatma Gandhi Memorial Medical College, Indore,

issues.text: What is the constitutional validity of r. 3 of the Rules for Selection of candidates for admission to the Pre-Professional B.Sc. Part 1 Course leading to M.B.B.S.?

anchor.surface_text: The only question raised in this writ petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution relates to the constitutional validity of r. 3 of the Rules for Selection of candidates for admission to the Pre-Professional B.Sc. Part 1 Course leading to M.B.B.S. in the Government Medical Colleges and for certain seats in the private Medical Colleges in the State of Mysore f

issues.text: Does r. 3 violate Art. 14 of the Constitution by imposing the condition of residence for a minimum period of ten years in the State of Mysore in addition to being domiciled there, creating an artificial classification suffering from unconstitutional discrimination?

anchor.surface_text: guaranteed by Art. 14 of the Constitution. According to his argument the impugned rule has, by imposing the condition of residence for a minimum period of ten years in the State of Mysore in addition to the condition of being domiciled in that State, created an artificial classification which suffers from unconstitutional discrimination

issues.text: Does fixing a period of ten years of residence have rational relationship or nexus with the object of selecting the best talent or most meritorious students for admission?

anchor.surface_text: Fixing a period of ten years of residence in the State according to Mr. Datar, is arbitrary and fanciful having no rational relationship or nexus with the object

issues.text: Is the rule repugnant to Article 15(1)?

anchor.surface_text: the contention that the rule is repugnant to article 15 1 must fail.

anchor.surface_text: guaranteed by Art. 14 of the Constitution. anchor.surface_text: between the Indian citizens domiciled in the State of Mysore who have resided there for ten years or more and those who have resided there for less than ten years. The period of ten years of residence selected in this rule is not only arbitrary but is highly unreasonable, based on no rational or intelligible principle, said the counsel. Its unreasonableness was illustrated by submitting that students normally pass the Pre-University Examination at the age of 16 or 17 years.

arguments.court_reasoning: Not shown to suffer from vice of unreasonableness; proper classification for state's needs

arguments.claim: 10-year residence deprives children of domiciled citizens temporarily residing outside state of medical education opportunity

anchor.surface_text: Its unreasonableness was illustrated by submitting that students normally pass the Pre-University Examination at the age of 16 or 17 years. To expect such students to have resided in the State of Mysore for ten years in order to, be eligible for admission to the Pre-Professional B.Sc. Part 1 Course leading to M.B.B.S. would mean that the children of those Indian citizens having their domicile in the State of Mysore who happen, for compelling reasons, to reside in other States in the Indian Union before their children have completed ten years of residence in the State of Mysore would be deprived of the opportunity of having medical education in their own State of domicile.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ed groups therefore cannot be challenged on the ground of inequality violating Art. 14. The impugned rule has number been shown by the petitioner to s

arguments.court_reasoning: Hardship cases do not render rule unconstitutional; policy matter

arguments.claim: If all states impose similar 10-year rules, children of mobile citizens cannot get admission anywhere

anchor.surface_text: This argument was elaborated by submitting that if all other States in the Union were also to frame similar rules insisting on residence for ten or more years then the children of those citizens, who are compelled by the necessity of earning their livelihood, to shift their residence from one State to another at short intervals, without completing ten years of residence in any one State, would never be able to get admission in any State.

arguments.claim: 10-year period has no rational relationship or nexus with object of selecting best talent or most meritorious students

anchor.surface_text: Fixing a period of ten years of residence in the State according to Mr. Datar, is arbitrary and fanciful having no rational relationship or nexus with the object or purpose of framing the rules, namely, of selecting the best talent or the most meritorious students for admission to the Medical Colleges.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: e object of selection can only be to secure the best possible material for admission to companyleges subject to the provision for socially and educati

arguments.court_reasoning: Distinguished as no nexus shown there; here nexus exists

arguments.claim: Sources classification valid if rational nexus to object (citing Chitra Ghosh)

anchor.surface_text: in support of the validity of the rule he drew our attention to the decision of this Court in Chitra Ghosh Another v. Union of India and Others 1 ... If the sources are properly classified whether on territorial, geographical or other reasonable basis it is not for the courts to interfere with the manner and method of making the classification.

arguments.claim: Domicile in rules means residence in popular sense, not technical (citing D.P. Joshi)

anchor.surface_text: in D. P. Joshi v. The State of Madhya Bharat and Another this Court had while upholding by majority the rules... laid down that in those rules the word domicile was used in its popular sense conveying the idea of residence.

arguments.court_reasoning: Applies same to r.3: domicile conveys intention to reside

arguments.claim: Word 'domicile' in r.3 conveys intention to reside or remain in Mysore

anchor.surface_text: In our view the word domicile as used in r. 3, in the present case is also used to convey the idea of intention to reside or remain in the State of Mysore.

arguments.claim: 10-year residence condition valid unless shown unreasonable; has nexus to selecting talent likely to serve state

anchor.surface_text: If classification based on residence does not impinge upon the principle of equality enshrined in Art. 14 as held by this Court in the decision already cited which is binding upon us, then the further condition of the residence in the State being there for at least ten years would also seem to be equally valid unless it is shown by the petitioner that selection of the period of ten years makes the classification so unreasonable...

arguments.claim: Rule constitutional; proper classification with merit selection from groups likely to serve state

anchor.surface_text: Proper classification inspired by this consideration and selection on merit from such classified groups therefore cannot be challenged on the ground of inequality violating Art. 14. The impugned rule has not been shown by the petitioner to suffer from the vice of unreasonableness.

arguments.claim: Hardships from rule do not make it unconstitutional

anchor.surface_text: The counter-affidavit filed by the State on the other hand discloses the purpose to be that of serving the interests of the residents of the State by providing medical aid for them. The petitioners argument that candidates whose parents have ,of necessity to remain out of Mysore State... merely suggests that there is a likelihood of some cases of hardship under the impugned rule. But ,cases of hardship are likely to arise... This, however, would not render the rule unconstitutional.

holdings.text: The impugned rule [r. 3] is constitutionally valid and does not violate Article 14.

anchor.surface_text: Proper classification inspired by this consideration and selection on merit from such classified groups therefore cannot be challenged on the ground of inequality violating Art. 14. The impugned rule has not been shown by the petitioner to suffer from the vice of unreasonableness.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Classification on 10-year residence has rational nexus to object of securing students likely to serve as doctors in the state; follows precedents like Chitra Ghosh and D.P. Joshi; not shown unreasonable.

holdings.text: Rule 3 does not violate Article 14 by creating an artificial and unreasonable classification based on 10-year residence.

holdings.text: The 10-year residence requirement has rational relationship or nexus with the object of the rules.

holdings.text: The rule is not repugnant to Article 15(1).

anchor.surface_text: In our view the word domicile as used in r. 3, in the present case is also used to convey the idea of intention to reside or remain in the State of Mysore.

holdings.text: Cases of hardship under the rule do not render it unconstitutional.
